statement:
A local minimum (resp. local maximum) of a convex function (resp.
concave function) on a convex subset of a topological vector space, is
always a global extremum.

Let $f:S\to \mathbb{R}$ be a convex function on a convex set $S$ in a
topological vector space.

Suppose $x$ is a local minimum for $f$; that is, there is an open
neighborhood $U$ of $x$ where $f(x) \leq f(\xi)$ for all $\xi\in U$. We
prove $f(x) \leq f(y)$ for arbitrary $y \in S$.

Consider the convex combination $(1-t)x + ty$ for $0 \leq t \leq 1$:

![image](convex-minimum.eps)

Since scalar multiplication and vector addition are, by definition,
continuous in a topological vector space, the convex combination
approaches $x$ as $t \to 0$. Therefore for small enough $t$,
$(1-t)x + ty$ is in the neighborhood $U$. Then $$\begin{aligned}
f(x) &\leq f\bigl(ty + (1-t) x\bigr)  & \text{for small $t > 0$} \\
&\leq t \, f(y) + (1-t) f(x) & \text{since $f$ is convex.}\end{aligned}$$
Rearranging , we have $f(x) \leq f(y)$.

To show the analogous situation for a concave function $f$, the above
reasoning can be applied after replacing $f$ with $-f$.
names: local minimum of convex function is necessarily global
local maximum of concave function is necessarily global
